msContents.summary: A Karaim translation of the Torah and the Haftarah

ab.title: Leviticus 5
ab.l:
And if a soul
sins: and hears the voice of a curse, and is a witness,
whether he has seen or known of it: if he does not tell of it,
he shall bear his punishment.

Or if a soul who touches any
unclean thing, whether it be a carcass of an unclean wild animal or
a carcass of unclean cattle, or a carcass of unclean
creeping animal, and it is hidden from him, and he had become unclean and
guilty,
Or if he touches the uncleanness of a man, of whatever sort the uncleanness may be with which he becomes unclean, and it is hidden from him, and then he had come to know and had become guilty,

Or if a soul swears so as to express
with his lips to do bad or to do good –
whatsoever it be that a man shall express with an oath — and it is hidden
from him, and he comes to know of it and he is guilty in one
of these:

And it shall be that when he shall become guilty by one
of these things that he shall confess that he has sinned in that thing,

And he shall bring his guilt offering to the Lord for his sin
which he has sinned, a female from the flock, a lamb or a kid of the goats,
for a sin offering. And the priest shall ask for atonement for him
from his sin.

And if his hand cannot attain enough for
a sheep, he shall bring his guilt offering for having sinned:
two turtledoves, or two young pigeons, to the Lord, one
for a sin offering, and one for a burnt offering.

And he shall bring
them to the priest, and he shall bring forward that which is for the sin offering first,
and wring off its head from the point opposite its back of the neck, but
shall not separate it.

And he shall sprinkle some of the blood of the sin offering
on the side of the altar, and the rest of the blood shall be drained out
at the base of the altar. It is a sin offering.

And
he shall make the second one a burnt offering, according to the |required| manner. And
the priest shall ask for atonement for him from his sin which he has
sinned, and it shall be forgiven him.

And if his hand cannot attain
enough for two turtledoves, or two young pigeons,
he shall bring as his offering for having sinned the tenth
part of an ephah of fine flour for a sin offering. He shall put no
oil on it and he shall put no frankincense on it, because it is a sin offering.

And he shall bring it to the priest, and
the priest shall take a full handful of it, his incense, and
burn it on the altar, next to the offerings by fire of the Lord. It is a sin offering.

And the priest shall ask for atonement for him, for his sin
that he has sinned in one of these, and
his sin will be forgiven. And it shall be the priest’s, as a grain offering.”’
And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

‘If a soul
commits a trespass, and sins by mistake among the holy things
of the Lord: he shall bring for his guilt offering to the Lord,
an unblemished ram from the flock with your valuation by mithqals of silver,
by the mithqal of the Holy, for a guilt offering.

And
for what he sinned from the Holy he shall pay and add to it the fifth
part of it and give it to the priest.
And the priest shall ask for atonement for him with the ram
of the guilt offering, and his sin will be forgiven.

And
if a soul who sins, commits one of the commandments
of the Lord that are not to be done, and did not know and became guilty,
he shall bear his punishment.

And he shall bring an unblemished ram
from the flock with your valuation for a guilt offering, to the priest,
and the priest shall ask for atonement for the mistake
that he made and knew it not, and his sin will be forgiven.

It is a guilt
offering: he has certainly become guilty to the Lord.’
And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying,

‘If a soul sins, and commits a trespass against the Lord, and deceives
his friend in |a matter of| deposit or |something| set in hand or by robbery,
or if he has oppressed his friend,

Or has found
something lost and lies about it and swears to a falsehood
— for one of any of these that a man does to sin by it:

And it shall be, if he has sinned and is guilty, he shall return
the spoil that he robbed or what he got by oppression
or the deposit that was deposited with him
or the lost thing that he found,

Or anything about which he has sworn to a falsehood, and he
shall pay it in full and shall add to it a fifth of it,
he shall give it to him to whom it belongs on the day of his being guilty.

And he shall bring his guilt offering
to the Lord: an unblemished ram from the flock with your valuation
for a guilt offering, to the priest.

And the priest shall ask for atonement
for him before the Lord, and his sin will be forgiven
for any one out of all that he has done to become guilty through it.’

app.note: K: shave; a mistranslation, cf. Heb. וּמָלַ֧ק ‘wring off’.
